item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Biden Urges U.S. to Remain ‘Beacon to the World’ in Aiding Allies at War
item.description: In an Oval Office speech, the president said that if terrorists and dictators weren’t stopped, “the cost and the threats to America” would keep rising. The address set the stage for his planned request to Congress for tens of billions of dollars in aid for Israel and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from an Israeli airstrike in Gaza’s southern city of Khan Younis on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Economy Starts to Rebound as It Adapts to War
item.description: Economists predict a return to growth, but many challenges lie ahead, including the rebuilding of war-torn cities and labor shortages.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shop damaged by shrapnel and bullet holes in the Kherson region of Ukraine. Economists say it will take many years for Ukraine’s economy to return to prewar levels.

item.title: Deal Lays Groundwork for Aid to Reach Desperate Gazans, Officials Say
item.description: Trucks loaded with food and medicine are lined up tantalizingly close to people who need it, separated only by border gates that war and diplomatic wrangling have kept closed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg, Emma Bubola, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Vivian Yee and Monika Pronczuk
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: People look through the rubble of a home in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, that was destroyed by an airstrike on Thursday.

item.title: Javier Milei and His 5 Cloned Dogs in Argentina’s Election
item.description: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian, might soon be Argentina’s next president. He credits his cloned “four-legged children.”
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Javier Milei at home in 2018 with his cloned mastiff puppies.

item.title: Photos: Life Under the Bombs in Khan Younis, Gaza
item.description: Civilians in Gaza face an unending nightmare of airstrikes and deprivation — if they manage to survive.
item.dc:creator: Samar Abu Elouf, Yousef Masoud and Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Medical workers with a boy, who was injured in a strike, at a hospital in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israelis Praise Biden Visit but Fear U.S. Constraints on Action
item.description: President Biden promised undying American backing for Israel in its war against Hamas. But that won’t mean U.S. support for everything Israel does.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Biden with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Tel Aviv on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is Hezbollah, the Group Posing a Threat to Israel from the North?
item.description: For decades, Hezbollah has been a significant force in Lebanon, wielding both political power and military strength — all while engaging in tit-for-tat skirmishes with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters carrying out training exercises during a news media visit to one of their camps in the village of Aaramta, in southern Lebanon, in May.

item.title: Russia Detains a U.S. Journalist, Alsu Kurmasheva
item.description: Alsu Kurmasheva, who holds dual U.S.-Russian citizenship and works in Prague, was charged with failing to register as a foreign agent after going to Russia for family reasons.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The newsroom of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty broadcaster in Moscow.

item.title: What South Korea’s Frequent Protests Say About Its Politics
item.description: Part rock concert, part revival meeting, the rallies reveal a country increasingly polarized over its leader, Yoon Suk Yeol.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee

item.title: China’s Military is Making Risky Moves and Adding Nuclear Warheads, U.S. Says
item.description: The Defense Department said in a report to Congress that Beijing’s “coercive” air intercepts were aimed at intimidating U.S. forces in the region.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: China has been stepping up military pressure on Taiwan, sending jets, drones, bombers and other planes near the island.

item.title: Protests Erupt Over ‘Horrific Scenes’ of Palestinians in Gaza
item.description: Not only Arabs in the street but, strikingly, also their rulers nearly uniformly condemned Israel for the Gaza hospital explosion and other violence affecting Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with Lebanese Army soldiers near the United States Embassy in Beirut on Wednesday.

item.title: With Putin by His Side, Xi Outlines His Vision of a New World Order
item.description: China’s close ties with Russia in countering American dominance point to a geopolitical rift that could shape the conflict between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Tiffany May
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, left, meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in Beijing, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Visits Israel and Putin Visits China Amid Gaza and Ukraine Wars
item.description: Washington’s strong support for Israel against Hamas is contrasted with Russian and Chinese efforts to align with the Palestinian struggle.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Biden arrived in Israel on Wednesday to show solidarity with Washington’s close ally in the Middle East.

item.title: Sign Up for Your Places: Global Update
item.description: All the latest news for any part of the world you select.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Canada Pulls 41 Diplomats as India Threatens to Revoke Their Immunity
item.description: The diplomats and 42 family members left amid growing tension over Canada’s assertion that India was complicit in the killing of a Sikh leader in British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Mélanie Joly, Canada’s foreign minister, right, sitting next to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, said that India’s plan to revoke diplomatic immunity was “unreasonable and escalatory.”

item.title: Israelis Can Travel to U.S. Without a Visa Under New Biden Program
item.description: The change should make it easier and faster for Israelis seeking to flee the war.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at Ben-Gurion International Airport near Lod, Israel, last week.

item.title: Mexico’s Top Human Rights Official Resigns, Handing Off Unsolved Mass Disappearance Case
item.description: Alejandro Encinas spent years investigating the high-profile case of 43 missing students, but said he was stepping down to work on a presidential election campaign.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Alejandro Encinas, a longtime friend and political ally of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, has been at odds with the Mexican armed forces.

item.title: Mainstream Republicans Opposing Jim Jordan’s Speaker Bid Dig In Against Him
item.description: Facing intimidation for opposing Jim Jordan’s speakership candidacy, mainstream Republicans are refusing to back down, defying their reputation for caving in the face of party clashes.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Representative Mariannette Miller-Meeks said she had received “credible death threats and a barrage of threatening calls” after voting against Representative Jim Jordan for speaker.

item.title: U.S. Shoots Down Several Missiles and Drones Launched From Yemen
item.description: A flurry of incidents underscored the heightened risks that the conflict between Israel and Hamas could spiral into a wider war.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ryan U. Kledzik/U.S. Naval Forces Europe-Africa, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by the U.S. Navy shows a Navy destroyer. A U.S. warship shot down three cruise missiles and several drones.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Gaza Aid Deal Sees Progress
item.description: Plus South Korea’s protest culture.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Humanitarian aid provided by the United Nations is loaded onto a United Arab Emirates Air Force C-130H-30 Hercules turboprop military transport aircraft at Dubai International Airport before departure for Cairo on Thursday.

item.title: Gaza Hospital Blast Death Toll Between 100-300, U.S. Officials Estimate
item.description: American officials say the blast on Tuesday likely killed 100 to 300 people. Gaza officials estimate the death toll closer to 500.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The scene outside the Al Ahli Hospital in Gaza, a day after a deadly explosion on Tuesday.

item.title: What the Laws of War Say About Forced Displacement and ‘Human Shields’
item.description: Amid the sorrow and anger over the ongoing violence, the core principles of humanitarian law are simple. Civilians must be protected.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians leaving the northern Gaza Strip, on their way south, near Khan Younis on Friday, Oct. 13.

item.title: Hurricane Norma Packs Powerful Winds as It Churns Toward Mexico
item.description: The Category 4 storm was expected to unleash heavy rain and likely cause flooding and mudslides in southern Baja California Sur this weekend, forecasters said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Hurricane Norma’s winds had reached 130 miles per hour as it approached the southern parts of Cabo San Lucas and the western coast of Mexico.

item.title: Van Gogh Museum Stops Giving Out Pikachu Cards After Pokémon Frenzy
item.description: The museum in Amsterdam stopped giving out Pikachu cards that were part of a special collaboration after extreme demand.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Remko de Waal/ANP, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam gave out special Pokémon cards to celebrate the museum’s 50th anniversary and recognize the link between the Dutch artist and Japan. Then things got nutty.

item.title: Chasing Jack the Ripper Through the Streets of Modern London
item.description: Tours devoted to the Victorian-era serial killer are thriving, even if the area they explore looks decidedly modern.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: The Five: The Untold Lives of the Women Killed by Jack the Ripper (Book)
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mick Priestly has been giving Jack the Ripper tours through Whitechapel for a decade.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Visits Israel in a Display of Support From U.K.
item.description: The British prime minister met his Israeli counterpart, Benjamin Netanyahu, during the trip, which follows a visit by President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain arriving at Ben Gurion Airport, near Tel Aviv, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: Republicans Use Israel Attack to Stoke Fears About U.S.-Mexico Border
item.description: G.O.P. lawmakers and candidates regularly invoke record-high border crossings to address a range of issues, including crime and jobs.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nikki Haley and other members of the Republican Party in trying to tie the Hamas attack to the United States’ southern border through sweeping and largely unsubstantiated claims.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s wartime visit to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden’s visit to Israel, including a meeting with Benjamin Netanyahu, has been complicated by a deadly hospital blast and rising tensions in the region.

item.title: Families of Hamas Hostages Split on Invasion of Gaza
item.description: The families are torn between wanting their loved ones returned safely at any cost and concern about more loss of life.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographs of Israelis believed to have been kidnapped by Hamas on Oct. 7 on display this week near the Israel Defense Forces’ headquarters in Tel Aviv.

item.title: First Venezuelan Migrants Deported Under New U.S. Policy Arrive
item.description: The deportation of migrants who had entered the U.S. illegally came as the Biden administration lifted some sanctions against Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Frances Robles
item.category: Chatham House (The Royal Institute of International Affairs)
item.media:credit: Veronica G. Cardenas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Migrants boarding a plane in Harlingen, Texas, on Wednesday for deportation to Venezuela.

item.title: 300 Arrested on Capitol Hill in Call for Cease-Fire in Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Rallies over the Israel-Hamas war have continued to be held across the country and in world capitals.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters asked for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war, inside the Cannon House Office Building on Wednesday.

item.title: Jacob Lew, Biden Nominee for Ambassador to Israel, Is Grilled by Senators
item.description: Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee accused Jacob Lew of having enabled the rise of Iran-backed terror groups as President Obama’s Treasury secretary.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacob J. Lew, President Biden’s nominee as the next U.S. ambassador to Israel, on Wednesday at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

item.title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Security Council Resolution on Israel-Hamas War
item.description: The American ambassador said the U.S. couldn’t support a measure that didn’t mention Israel’s right to self-defense.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Linda Thomas-Greenfield, right, the American ambassador to the United Nations, used the United States’ veto power to block a Security Council resolution on the Israel-Hamas war on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Says Israel Didn’t Cause Hospital Blast, as Biden Promises Aid to Gaza
item.description: President Biden backed Israel’s claim that a Gaza City explosion that killed hundreds, which Hamas blamed on Israel, had come from a failed rocket launch by an armed Palestinian group.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Peter Baker, Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden was greeted by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on his arrival in Israel on Wednesday.

item.title: Devastation in Gaza After Hospital Blast
item.description: Still reeling from an explosion outside Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, medical workers spoke of the destruction that left hundreds there dead. “We haven’t seen anything like this in our lives,” said one doctor.
item.dc:creator: Soliman Hijjy, Mark Boyer, Chevaz Clarke and Neil Collier
item.media:credit: Soliman Hijjy for The New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Biden Backs Israel on the Hospital Blast
item.description: Plus how much do we know about A.I.?
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden yesterday after meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Brings Tensions to Europe: What Travelers Need to Know
item.description: The intensifying war in the Middle East has led to demonstrations in London, Paris, Rome and beyond. Here’s what to expect amid the disruptions.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: Protesters light flares and wave flags during an unauthorized pro-Palestinian demonstration at the Place de la République in Paris last week.

item.title: Liberia’s Presidential Election Goes to a Runoff
item.description: George Weah, a former soccer star who has been president since 2018, ran neck and neck with his main opponent in a rematch of the West African country’s last such contest.
item.dc:creator: Clair MacDougall and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Looking at newspaper headlines this past week in Monrovia, the Liberian capital. None of the candidates in the election drew the 50 percent needed for a first-round victory.

item.title: Gaza Hospital Explosion: What We Know
item.description: Much is unclear about the strike that Palestinian authorities say killed hundreds.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Soliman Hijjy for The New York Times

item.title: Why Is Gaza’s Rafah Border Crossing With Egypt So Important?
item.description: The access point, where aid trucks are waiting to enter from Egypt and people are waiting to leave, is the only land crossing into Gaza that is not controlled by Israel.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rafah border crossing between the Gaza Strip and Egypt on Monday. It is the only access point not controlled by Israel where civilians can enter and leave Gaza by land.

item.title: Humanitarian Aid for Gaza Amasses at Egypt’s Border as Crisis Worsens
item.description: Though the U.S. and Israel say they have cleared the way for the aid to make its way into Gaza, truckloads of supplies remain in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Mourad Hijazy
item.media:description: A convoy of trucks carrying aid was parked on the Egypt side of the Rafah border crossing with Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: Early Intelligence Suggests Hospital Blast Caused by Palestinian Fighters, U.S. Says
item.description: U.S. officials cautioned that the analysis is preliminary and that the United States was continuing to collect and analyze evidence.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Patrick Kingsley, Helene Cooper and Adam Entous
item.media:description: A blast killed hundreds of people at a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday.

item.title: Storm Babet Brings Heavy Rain to Scotland
item.description: Britain’s weather agency warned that as much as a month’s worth of rain is expected to fall between Thursday and Friday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Residents at a flood barrier in the village of Edzell, near the eastern shore of Scotland, on Thursday.

item.title: The Israeli military puts forward its version of what happened at the hospital in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: People searching through debris outside the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza on Wednesday following a deadly blast there.

item.title: After Gaza Hospital Explosion, Bloody Blankets and ‘Lots of Bodies’
item.description: “We’ve never lived through a war this intense,” said a Palestinian journalist who captured the aftermath of the blast in Gaza that killed hundreds.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Hiba Yazbek and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.media:description: The aftermath of an explosion at the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City on Wednesday. Hundreds were killed, Gaza health authorities said.

item.title: Putin Plays Down Threat Posed by Powerful U.S.-Supplied Missiles
item.description: Analysts say the long-range weapons could force Russia to move military assets further away from the front lines, undermining their operations.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Constant Méheut and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A residential building in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Wednesday after it was hit by a missile.

item.title: Allied Spy Chiefs Warn of Chinese Espionage Targeting Tech Firms
item.description: F.B.I. officials say more than half of Chinese spying efforts aimed at stealing technology occurs in Silicon Valley.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: “We are dealing with another unprecedented threat,” said Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director. “There is no greater threat to innovation than the Chinese government.”

item.title: Biden Walks a Tightrope on Israel-Gaza as Democratic Tensions Smolder
item.description: The president has won bipartisan plaudits for his response to the war, and his trip to Israel offers a chance to appear statesmanlike. But anger on the left is growing as Israeli strikes pound Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: President Biden on his way to Israel. He has expressed firm support for the country after a Hamas attack that killed more than 1,400 Israelis.

item.title: Biden Tells Israel that Gaza Hospital Blast Appears to Be ‘Done By the Other Team’
item.description: In a rare wartime visit, President Biden paired his support for Israel with a plea not to let overwhelming grief or anger drive the country to go too far.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker

item.title: Here’s the latest on the war.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Hundreds of people have died in an explosion at a hospital in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Palestinian civilians at the Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza on Tuesday. They were taken there after they were wounded in what Gaza officials said was an airstrike on the Ahli Arab Hospital.

item.title: Everton Sale Stalls Amid New Questions About 777 Partners
item.description: The U.S. firm bidding for the Premier League club, 777 Partners, has failed to provide required information to a British regulator.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: A sliding Everton player during a Premier League match against Tottenham in April. Everton’s finances are so dire that the club requires monthly infusions of millions of dollars to keep operating.

item.title: Hundreds Feared Dead in Gaza Hospital Blast as Israel and Hamas Blame Each Other
item.description: With President Biden about to arrive in Israel, Palestinians and Israelis blamed each other for the explosion at a hospital, where people had sought shelter from Israeli bombing.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Hiba Yazbek
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: World Leaders Express Horror Over Deadly Gaza Hospital Blast
item.description: Expressions of horror over the large loss of life predominated, while many Arab governments stressed certainty that Israel was to blame.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Emergency responders delivering a civilian with injuries to a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden ‘Outraged’ Over Gaza Blast as He Makes a Wartime Visit to Israel
item.description: The explosion at a hospital highlights the dangers of a trip at a volatile moment in the war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Peter Baker
item.media:description: Palestinian civilians after a blast at a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday. “We mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy,” President Biden said.

item.title: Venezuela Pledges Small Steps Toward Fair Elections Next Year
item.description: The agreement signed on Tuesday by the country’s authoritarian government and the opposition would not allow all candidates to run.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Julie Turkewitz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street market in Caracas in January. An economic crisis that has lasted for years has sparked a humanitarian crisis that has caused extensive migration.

item.title: U.S. Response to Israel-Hamas War Draws Fury in Mideast
item.description: The staunch support for Israel has stoked accusations of American hypocrisy, with Arab critics fearing a wholesale massacre of Palestinians in response to the deadly Hamas attack on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim, Alissa J. Rubin and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers around a mortar launcher firing toward Gaza from Be’eri, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: What Is Islamic Jihad, the Group Israel Blamed for the Gaza Hospital Blast?
item.description: Like Hamas, the group receives support from Iran in funding and weapons.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Islamic Jihad supporters at a rally for the 35th anniversary of the group’s founding, in Gaza City last October.
